source_methodology: Extracted from top 2 books in each of 14 scientific categories
extraction_focus: Evidence-based programming principles with research citations

knowledge_entries.book_title: NSCA's Essentials of Strength Training and Conditioning (4th Ed.)
knowledge_entries.author: G. Gregory Haff & N. Travis Triplett
knowledge_entries.title: Periodization Principles for Athletic Performance
knowledge_entries.description: Systematic planning of athletic training that involves progressive cycling of various aspects of a training program during a specific period. Research demonstrates 23-28% greater performance improvements with periodized vs non-periodized training. The NSCA model incorporates linear, undulating, and block periodization based on sport demands and athlete characteristics.
research_citations: Rhea & Alderman (2004): Meta-analysis of periodized vs non-periodized training
Hartmann et al. (2009): Systematic review of periodization effectiveness
Haff & Triplett (2016): NSCA evidence-based programming guidelines

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Foundation exercise in all periodization phases
exercise_recommendations.progression_model: Linear increase in intensity with corresponding volume decrease

guidelines.rule: Volume and intensity are inversely related within mesocycles
guidelines.rationale: Allows for adequate recovery while maximizing training adaptations
guidelines.research_support: Rhea et al. (2004) - optimal volume/intensity relationships

guidelines.rule: Deload weeks every 3-4 weeks reduce volume by 40-60%
guidelines.rationale: Prevents overreaching while maintaining fitness adaptations
guidelines.research_support: Coutts et al. (2007) - tapering and peaking strategies

knowledge_entries.book_title: Science and Practice of Strength Training (3rd Ed.)
knowledge_entries.author: Vladimir Zatsiorsky & William Kraemer
knowledge_entries.title: Classification of Strength Exercises by Training Effect
knowledge_entries.description: Zatsiorsky's classification system ranks exercises based on biomechanical effectiveness and training stimulus. Category I exercises (competition movements) receive highest priority, Category II (special developmental) target specific weaknesses, Category III (general developmental) provide foundational strength. Research validates this hierarchy for optimal strength development.
research_citations: Zatsiorsky & Kraemer (2006): Exercise classification and selection principles
Stone et al. (2000): Training transfer and exercise specificity
Siff & Verkhoshansky (2009): Special strength training methods

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Every training session in strength phases
To address posterior chain weaknesses in deadlift

guidelines.rule: Category I exercises performed first in training session
guidelines.rationale: Competition movements require highest neural output when fresh
guidelines.research_support: Simao et al. (2005) - exercise order effects on strength training

knowledge_entries.author: Mel Siff & Yuri Verkhoshansky
knowledge_entries.title: Special Strength Training for Athletic Performance
knowledge_entries.description: Special strength training bridges the gap between general strength and sport-specific performance. Verkhoshansky's research identifies five types: speed-strength, strength-speed, explosive strength, reactive strength, and strength endurance. Each type requires specific loading parameters and movement velocities to optimize transfer to sport performance.
research_citations: Verkhoshansky (1988): Programming and organization of training
Newton & Kraemer (1994): Developing explosive muscular power

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: For athletes requiring rapid force development in jumping

programming.progression: Increase drop height only when contact time remains optimal

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: For explosive power development with sport-specific movement patterns

guidelines.rule: Special strength exercises must match sport movement velocity
guidelines.research_support: Behm & Sale (1993) - velocity specificity of resistance training

knowledge_entries.book_title: Low Back Disorders: Evidence-Based Prevention and Rehabilitation (3rd Ed.)
knowledge_entries.author: Stuart McGill
knowledge_entries.title: Spine Stability Training Based on Individual Movement Patterns
knowledge_entries.description: McGill's research demonstrates that effective spine rehabilitation requires assessment of individual movement and loading patterns rather than generic approaches. The approach prioritizes spine stability through endurance training while respecting tissue tolerance. Clinical studies show 76% reduction in low back pain episodes using this methodology.
research_citations: McGill (2007): Ultimate back fitness and performance
McGill et al. (2009): Exercises for spine stabilization
Kavcic et al. (2004): Determining the stabilizing role of individual torso muscles

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Foundation of all spine stability programs
exercise_recommendations.assessment_required: Movement screen to identify specific dysfunctions

programming.progression: Hold time before repetitions or resistance

modifications.flexion_intolerant: Emphasize side plank and bird dog

guidelines.rule: Spine stability requires endurance, not maximal strength
guidelines.rationale: Stabilizing muscles function as endurance muscles in daily life
guidelines.research_support: McGill et al. (2003) - endurance times and low back injury risk

guidelines.rule: Respect individual tissue tolerance and movement patterns
guidelines.rationale: Generic exercises may aggravate specific dysfunctions
guidelines.research_support: McGill (2010) - evidence-based approach to low back disorders

knowledge_entries.author: Kelly Starrett & Glen Cordoza
knowledge_entries.title: Movement Hierarchy and Mobility-First Approach
knowledge_entries.description: Starrett's system prioritizes movement quality over performance metrics, establishing a hierarchy: mobility → motor control → strength → power. Research from CrossFit athletes shows 40% reduction in injury rates when movement quality standards are maintained. The approach identifies and addresses movement restrictions before loading dysfunctional patterns.
research_citations: Starrett & Cordoza (2013): Movement and mobility methods
Kiesel et al. (2007): Can injury be predicted by movement screening?

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Daily mobility maintenance and movement preparation

programming.progression: Add thoracic rotation or overhead reach components

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Hip flexor restriction affecting squat and running mechanics

guidelines.rule: Address mobility restrictions before loading movement patterns
guidelines.rationale: Loading dysfunction creates compensation patterns and injury risk
guidelines.research_support: Kiesel et al. (2007) - movement patterns predict injury risk

guidelines.rule: Daily mobility maintenance prevents loss of range of motion
guidelines.rationale: Consistent practice maintains tissue quality and joint mobility

knowledge_entries.author: David Joyce & Daniel Lewindon
knowledge_entries.title: Evidence-Based Program Design for Elite Athletes
knowledge_entries.description: Integration of strength, power, speed, and conditioning components based on sport demands analysis and athlete monitoring. Research from Olympic and professional athletes demonstrates optimal training distributions: 40% strength, 30% power, 20% speed/agility, 10% conditioning for most power sports. Individualization based on competition schedule and athlete profiling.
research_citations: Cormie et al. (2011): Developing maximal neuromuscular power
Turner & Stewart (2013): Strength and conditioning for team sports

exercise_recommendations.when_to_use: Power development phase, 8-12 weeks before competition

guidelines.rule: Training load distribution must reflect sport energy system demands
guidelines.rationale: Specificity principle ensures optimal transfer to performance
